description:
Calling all developers!

Welcome to the Agent Development Kit Hackathon with Google Cloud. Everyone's talking about AI agents, but the real magic happens when they collaborate to tackle complex tasks - think complex processes, data analysis, content creation, and customer support. In this hackathon, you'll build autonomous multi-agent AI systems using Google Cloud and the open source Agent Development Kit (ADK). 

This is your chance to dive deep into cutting-edge AI, showcase your skills, and contribute to the future of agent development.
requirements:
Requirements

What to Build

Your project should demonstrate how to design and orchestrate interactions between multiple autonomous agents using ADK. Build your solutions within one of the following categories:

  • Automation of Complex Processes: Design multi-agent workflows to automate complex, multi-step business processes, software development lifecycle, or manage intricate tasks.
  • Data Analysis and Insights: Create multi-agent systems that autonomously analyze data from various sources, derive meaningful insights using tools like BigQuery, and collaboratively present findings.
  • Customer Service and Engagement: Develop intelligent virtual assistants or support agents built with ADK as multi-agent systems to handle complex customer inquiries, provide personalized support, and proactively engage with customers.
  • Content Creation and Generation: Build multi-agent systems that can autonomously generate different forms of content, such as marketing materials, reports, or code, by orchestrating agents with specialized content generation capabilities.

Your project must be built using Agent Development Kit and you must focus on the design and orchestration of interactions between multiple agents using ADK. While ADK is foundational, you are allowed and encouraged to enhance your solutions by integrating with other relevant technologies and frameworks within the Google Cloud ecosystem.

The project must be capable of being successfully installed and must function as depicted in the video and/or expressed in the text description.

 

What to Submit
  • Include a URL to the hosted Project for judging and testing.
  • Include a text description that includes a summary of the Project’s features and functionality, technologies used, information about any other data sources used, and your findings and learnings as you worked through the project. Written parts of entries must be in English to be eligible.  The Submission must, at a minimum, support English language use.
  • Include a URL to your public code repository to show how your project was built. The code repository must be public to allow access for judging and testing. By submitting this code, you confirm you have the authority and right to share the code for the purposes described in this Contest.
  • Include an Architecture Diagram showing which technologies were used and how they interact with one another.
  • Include a demonstration video of your Project. The video portion of the submission must meet the following criteria:
    • Should include footage that shows the Project functioning on the platform(s) for which it was built.
    • No parts of the submission can be derogatory, offensive, threatening, defamatory, disparaging, libelous or contain any content that is inappropriate, indecent, sexual, profane, indecent, tortuous, slanderous, discriminatory in any way, or that promotes hatred or harm against any group or person, or otherwise does not comply with the theme and spirit of the Contest.
    • No part of that submission contains content, material or any element that is unlawful, or otherwise in violation of or contrary to all applicable federal, state, or local laws and regulations in any country,  state or applicable territory where you created the video and in the United States.
    • The Submission must not contain any content, material or element that displays any third party advertising, slogan, logo, trademark or otherwise indicates a sponsorship or endorsement by a third party, commercial entity or that is not within the spirit of the Contest, as determined by Sponsor, in its sole discretion.  
    • The Submission must be an original, unpublished work that does not contain, incorporate or otherwise use any content, material or element that is owned by a third party or entity.
    • It cannot contain any content, element, or material that violates a third party’s publicity, privacy or intellectual property rights.
    • It should not be longer than 3 minutes.  If it is longer than 3 minutes, only the first 3 minutes will be evaluated.
    • It must conform to the technical requirements set forth on the Contest site, including that the Submission must be uploaded to and made publicly visible on YouTube or Vimeo, and a link to the video must be provided on the Submission form on the Contest Site.
    • It must be in English or include English subtitles. 

 

Check out the rules tab for full details on submissions.

 

Start learning about AI agents on Google Cloud here.

judging:
Judging Criteria

  • Technical Implementation (50%)
    How well is the solution executed? Is the code clean, efficient, and well-documented? How effectively does it utilize the core concepts of Agent Development Kit? Did the project showcase the use of multiple AI agents working together to achieve tasks?
  • Innovation and Creativity (30%)
    How novel and original is the idea? Does it address a significant problem or create a unique solution?
  • Demo and Documentation (20%)
    Is the problem clearly defined, and is the solution effectively presented through a demo and documentation? Have they explained how they used Agent Development Kit and relevant tools? Have they included an architectural diagram?
  • Bonus Points
    Submitting the following optional components will positively impact the score the submission receives from the Judges.
  • a) A published blog post, video, or podcast
    Cover how the project was built using Agent Development Kit. Include language that says you created the content for the purposes of entering this hackathon. For any social media posts, include the hashtag #adkhackathon. See Full Rules for Details.
  • b) A contribution to the Agent Development Kit open source repository
    Show your commits, pull requests, issues opened, and code reviews by linking to your GitHub profile or the repository's contribution history. See Full Rules for Details.
  • c) The use of Google Cloud technology
    includes, but is not limited to Agent Engine, Cloud Run, and BigQuery, or Google AI models. See Full Rules for Details.

description:
Ready to build the future on the cloud?

Join us for an electrifying hackathon where you'll harness the game-changing power of Google Cloud. Dive into a world of cutting-edge AI, machine learning, and limitless cloud computing resources designed to help you build, deploy, and scale your boldest ideas. Unleash the potential of powerful data analytics, secure storage, and robust security services – all engineered to fuel innovation at any scale. Explore curated and public datasets, and get hands-on with Google Cloud's advanced AI tools to bring your most innovative projects to life.

We're thrilled to be partnering with MongoDB and GitLab for this hackathon!
requirements:
Requirements

WHAT TO BUILD

  • MongoDB Challenge: Select any public dataset that sparks your interest and, using AI for analysis and generation— alongside MongoDB’s powerful search and vector search and our Google integrations— create a solution that helps users understand, interact with, or gain new perspectives from the data that shapes our world. 

  • GitLab Challenge: Create an AI-enabled app using GitLab and Google Cloud. Show us how you're building Software. Faster. Submissions are encouraged to include contributions to GitLab’s Community Edition (CE) or functional components submitted to the GitLab CI/CD Catalog.

WHAT TO SUBMIT

  • Include a URL to the hosted Project for judging and testing.

  • Include a URL to your Open Source code repository to show how your project was built. 

  • Include a demo video (3 minutes). Videos must be uploaded to YouTube or Vimeo, and made public.

    • Judges will not be required to watch beyond 3 minutes

  • Select which challenge you’ll be submitting for.

  • Your completed Devpost submission form.

Please check the Official Rules for full details.

ABOUT THE PARTNERS

MongoDB

Explore the power of MongoDB's intelligent data platform to build innovative AI-driven solutions for real-world impact. Discover how MongoDB's flexible and scalable architecture, coupled with its AI application ecosystem, enables the development of sophisticated applications. Leverage advanced data handling and integration capabilities to enhance operational efficiency and create meaningful change across various sectors.

GitLab

GitLab is the most comprehensive AI-powered DevSecOps platform for software innovation. GitLab enables organizations to increase developer productivity, improve operational efficiency, reduce security and compliance risk, and accelerate digital transformation. More than 40 million registered users and more than 50% of the Fortune 100 trust GitLab to ship better, more secure software faster.

  • Quality of the Idea
    How creative and unique is the project?

description:
We’re hosting the first global Perplexity hackathon, powered by Perplexity’s Sonar API!

Sonar lets developers build apps with the best AI answer engine: a fast, affordable API offering with the features that millions of Perplexity users love, including real-time internet search and trusted citations.

Advanced Sonar offerings such as Sonar Reasoning, Sonar Reasoning Pro, and Sonar Deep Research let developers build custom research agents that support follow up questions and expose chain-of-thought.

We’re looking for developers to push the boundaries of what’s possible with Sonar and dream up entirely new product categories. If you’ve been thinking about shipping the “Perplexity for ____”, there’s never been a better time to start building.

Check out the following:

    • More info about Sonar
    • How to generate your API key and start building
    • Sonar developer docs
requirements:
Requirements

What to Build

  • Build or update an app powered by Perplexity’s Sonar API

What to Submit

  • Include a video (about 3 minutes) that demonstrates your submission. Videos must be uploaded to YouTube, Vimeo, or Facebook Video and made public.

    • Judges will not be required to watch beyond 3 minutes

  • Provide a URL to your private code repository for judging and testing.

    • Include a detailed README.md
    • Share your private repo with james.liounis@perplexity.ai & testing@devpost.com

  • Include an explanation of how Perplexity API was used.

  • Identify which category you are submitting into.

  • Your completed Devpost submission form.

Please check the Official Rules for full details.

judging:
Judging Criteria

  • Technological Implementation
    Does the project demonstrate quality software development? Does the project thoroughly leverage the required tool? How is the quality of the code?
  • Design
    Is the user experience and design of the project well thought out? Is there a balanced blend of frontend and backend in the software?
  • Potential Impact
    How big of an impact could the project have on the target community? How big of an impact could it have beyond the target community?
  • Quality of the Idea
    How creative and unique is the project? Does the concept exist already? If so, how much does the project improve on it?

description:
Welcome to the HP AI Studio & NVIDIA Developer Challenge! 

We're thrilled you're joining us to build innovative, open-source AI solutions that could transform industries. Before registering, please review the hardware requirements below to ensure you have the necessary setup for a smooth and successful hackathon experience. 

This competition is open to U.S. residents only and entitlements of HP AI Studio are limited to the first 1,000 eligible participants

Why HP AI Studio for Local AI Development?

HP AI Studio is a secure, collaborative workspace with containerization for local development, empowering teams to quickly get started with pre-configured workspaces. Co-engineered with NVIDIA and integrated with NVIDIA NGC libraries, HP AI Studio provides seamless on-prem access to optimized AI tools, ensuring maximum performance, security, and flexibility for local AI workflows. 

At its core, HP's AI Workstation portfolio—including HP mobile and desktop workstations powered by NVIDIA RTX GPUs—delivers unmatched performance for local AI creation. By eliminating reliance on cloud infrastructure, HP AI Studio enables fast, secure, and cost-efficient AI development, right on your own hardware. Together, HP and NVIDIA are redefining how AI is developed—locally, securely, and without compromise.  

Your insights matter! As you explore HP AI Studio, we’d love to hear your feedback on how we can make it even better for local AI development. Share your thoughts, challenges, and ideas in Discord to help shape the future of AI innovation.

We can't wait to see what you create!

 

HARDWARE REQUIREMENTS 

A Windows 10 (build 19041 and higher) or 11 or Linux Ubuntu 22.04 OS. WSL 2 (Windows Subsystem for Linux) must be enabled on setups running Windows OS. Refer to WSL Recommended Setup for more details. 

  • CPU: Intel Core™ i5 12th gen or AMD Ryzen™ 9 or higher processors 
  • GPU: NVIDIA® GPU card with CUDA® Compute capability driver version 528.89 or newer. For best performance we recommend working on the latest stable version. 
  • Storage: Minimum 50 GB of available storage 
  • VRAM: Minimum 8GB 
  • RAM: Minimum 16GB 

 

WHY JOIN?
  • Build cutting-edge AI apps: Gain hands-on experience with HP AI Studio, boosting your skills and resume. 
  • Make a real-world impact: Develop open-source AI solutions that could transform industries and benefit society. 
  • Shape the future of AI tools: Provide valuable feedback on HP AI Studio, influencing product roadmap and features as an early adopter. 
  • Test drive cutting-edge technology: Be among the first to explore HP AI Studio's capabilities for local, on-premise AI development. 
  • Collaborate and connect: Join a vibrant community of talented developers from around the world. Share ideas, learn from each other, and build lasting connections. 

Don’t miss your shot at a new HP Workstation

Did you know that by activating your HP AI Studio account, you're automatically entered into a sweepstakes to win a FREE HP ZBook Fury G10 16" Mobile Workstation (valued at $5,000)?

It's that simple! If you've already registered for the HP + NVIDIA Challenge and received your AI Studio entitlement, all you need to do is activate your license and log into AI Studio before May 23rd at 11:59 PM PT to be eligible.

Don't miss out on this incredible opportunity! Take these quick steps now:

  1. Register (or be registered) to the HP + NVIDIA Challenge
  2. Receive an AI Studio entitlement from HP (be sure to check your SPAM folder)
  3. Activate your license
  4. Log into AI Studio

If you already completed these four steps, you’re automatically in the running!

Full Sweepstakes Rules

 

WHAT TO EXPECT

We're excited for you to explore HP AI Studio, an evolving platform designed to power local AI development. This competition is open to U.S. participants only and limited to 1,000 accounts. 

This is your opportunity to influence product development—your participation will help shape the future of AI Studio. As we continue refining the experience, expect some bumps along the way. We recommend focusing on available AI Studio tools and limiting workspace image customizations to pip libraries as Linux package updates will not persist in the container in the current version of the software.

Your insights matter! Share local AI tips, challenges, feedback, and share ideas to help us improve through the Discord channel.

Build with us and be part of the future of local, on-prem AI development on HP AI Studio. We can’t wait to see what you create! 

Be sure to keep an eye on updates throughout the hackathon to incorporate the newest features.
requirements:
Requirements

WHAT TO BUILD

Develop an AI-powered web app using HP AI Studio tools

  • Explore example AI Studio projects on GitHub for inspiration and sample code on registering models with MLflow. 
  • Utilize AI Studio workspace images or create a custom image by modifying pip libraries or providing a requirements.txt file to the custom workspace to fit your needs. 

 Important Note:

  • apt-get packages can be installed via the terminal within a workspace (e.g., sudo apt-get install libjpeg-dev libpng-dev libtiff-dev for OpenCV support). 
  • However, these will not persist in this version of AI Studio. 
  • To avoid having to repeat Linux package updates each time a workspace is restarted, use existing AI Studio workspace images. 
  • If your project requires Linux package updates (e.g. libjpeg-dev), we are documenting steps to re-install or leaving the workspace running until the model is registered. 
  • pip libraries added through the customization feature will persist across sessions. 

Your solution should showcase HP AI Studio's capabilities while addressing real-world industry challenges in a maximum of one of the following categories: 

  • Automotive Manufacturing  
  • Healthcare 
  • Finance 
  • Retail 
  • Technology 
 
Working with HP AI Studio

Getting Started

 Get Access: After registration, check your email for HP AI Studio access credentials. If you experience any access issues, refer to the support email provided in your entitlement email. Need help? Ping the HP team in Discord for tips and questions about the hackathon. 

Join HP’s AI creator community to stay current on AI Studio updates, demos, tools, and news. After installation, submit support tickets in-app for technical support.

Start Building: Follow our 45-minute tutorial to create your first project. Check the resource library on github for sample projects and product overviews to get up to speed quickly.

Find Inspiration: Explore example projects and code samples on the Resources tab to spark new ideas.

 

Development Best Practices

Use AI Studio Tools: Leverage the full suite of HP AI Studio tools and resources for streamlined AI development.

Workspace Customization: If modifying your workspace, limit changes to pip libraries, as Linux package updates within a running container will not persist.

Model Management: Use MLflow in AI Studio to register models for local deployment, organize artifacts, and set hooks to track performance via the monitor tab.

Deployment: Deploy models to Swagger through AI Studio for standardized API access.

Application Development: Build an industry-specific AI web app that tackles real-world challenges. Create a ‘demo’ folder in MLflow to generate and store artifacts. Web files in the demo folder will automatically deploy in Swagger. Alternatively, create the web app outside of AI Studio, locally host the web app server, and point your web app to the Swagger endpoint.

Deployment Options: Publish your web app for local inference.

 

WHAT TO SUBMIT

Head over the What to Submit tab for specifics.

judging:
Judging Criteria

  • AI Innovation (25%)
    • Innovative use of generative AI, agentic AI, or other AI capabilities • Integration of multiple AI modalities where appropriate • Novel approaches to industry-specific challenges • Efficiency and performance of AI implementation
  • Demonstration and Documentation (25%)
    • Clarity and quality of demo video • UI/UX design • Comprehensiveness of documentation • Clear explanation of AI Studio's role in the project • Quality of setup and deployment instructions (make sure NOT to add any secret APIs)
  • Industry Impact (25%)
    • Potential impact on the target industry • Addresses significant real-world challenges • Scalability and practicality of the solution • Potential adoption beyond initial use case
  • Originality and Creativity (25%)
    • Uniqueness of the concept • Creative application of AI Studio capabilities • Improvement over existing solutions • Innovative user experience

description:
About the challenge

Join us for an innovative worldwide virtual challenge designed to accelerate the development of AI solutions promoting digital inclusion. Through cross-industry collaboration, we aim to crowdsource ideas and design artifacts for frictionless, secure, and sustainable frameworks that integrate leading AI models with AWS services, enabling equitable digital experiences for all. Curious what to build but not sure where to start? You can view our previous in-person winner, Learn AI, or take a look at our previous in-person hackathon.

In parallel with the hackathon itself, you can also check out our Breaking Barriers Skills Challenge!
requirements:
Requirements

What to Build

Build an innovative application that combines AWS generative AI services with next-generation connectivity solutions (like 5G, IoT, or edge computing) to solve pressing challenges in healthcare, education, sustainability, or arts & culture. Your solution should demonstrate how Telecommunications networks and AI can work together to create more accessible and impactful digital experiences for all users.

Key requirements for your application include:

  • Must use AWS generative AI services (such as Amazon Bedrock, Amazon SageMaker AI or Amazon Q)
  • Must demonstrate measurable real-world impact
  • Should have a clean, intuitive user interface
  • Must be technically sound and well-engineered

What to Submit 

  • Write Up. The problem statement you set out to solve, the solution overview, and potential impact that this solution can deliver for society at-large.
  • Code. Provide a URL to your open source public code repository for judging and testing.
  • Video. Include a demo video (about 5 minutes). The video should highlight your project’s features and show how to interact with the required technology in your project. Judges are not required to watch beyond the requested video length.

judging:
Judging Criteria

  • Technological Implementation
    Does the project demonstrate quality software development? Does the project thoroughly leverage AWS generative AI services? How is the quality of the code?
  • Design
    Is the user experience and design of the project well thought out? Is there a balanced blend of frontend and backend in the software?
  • Potential Impact
    How big of an impact could the project have on the generative AI community? How big of an impact could it have beyond the target community?
  • Quality of the Idea
    How creative and unique is the project? Does the concept exist already? If so, how much does the project improve on it?

description:
Welcome to the Officail Hackathon for bitcoin 2025!

This is the submission site for the Bitcoin 2025 conference hackathon. This is an online hackathon taking place from April 7th to May 20th. 

The main hackathon competition will be open ended (overall 1st, 2nd, 3rd). Anything involving bitcoin is fair game.

There are optional challenges that hackers may create projects around. Submitting for a challenge is optional, and ALL projects will be considered for the main competition.

Schedule 

Kickoff: April 7th
Submission Deadline: May 20th @ 8:00 PM ET (11:59 PM UTC) on devpost
Winners Announced: May 29th at Bitcoin 2025 in Las Vegas
requirements:
Requirements

Your team must follow the rules. Read the rules here.

All teams must submit their projects on Devpost (this site) before the submission deadline (May 20th). Do this early so you don't forget.

Your submission must contain the following:
- REQUIRED - A demo video to show off your project (3-5 minutes MAX)
- REQUIRED - A link to your code repository (github, etc.) 
- optional - A link to a live preview of your project

Submission Deadline: May 20th @ 8:00 PM ET (11:59 PM UTC)

Best use of exSat
$10,000 of Bitcoin
1 winner

$10,000 in bitcoin + an additional $10,000 in bitcoin to continue work after the hackathon. This prize will be awarded to the project that best utilizes the exSat platform.

exSat Extends Bitcoin's metadata consensus with a Hybrid Mechanism (PoW + PoS), aiming to bring Bitcoin's powerful and well-established trust to the entire blockchain ecosystem.

We welcome any projects that are beneficial to the development of BTC ecosystem, including but not limited to: infrastructure projects, PayFi and Bitcoin DeFi, asset issuance platforms, RWA projects, and one-stop passkey solutions.

Sponsored by exSat - https://exsat.network/

Best use of sBTC
$8,000 of Bitcoin
1 winner

1st Place - $4000 in bitcoin
2nd Place - $2500 in bitcoin
3rd Place - $1500 in bitcoin

Build innovative DeFi applications on the Stacks blockchain that leverage sBTC—a 1:1 Bitcoin-backed asset that enables programmability without compromising Bitcoin's security. This hackathon offers builders a unique opportunity to be at the forefront of Bitcoin DeFi innovation.

Read the full challenge description & submission requirements here: https://stacksfoundation.notion.site/Stacks-Track-Bitcoin-Vegas-Hackathon-1ced6d1686088003a94afaaaae03ed69

Most Educational
1 winner

Best Student Hack
1 winner

Tickets to a future Bitcoin++ event - Only eligible to teams where EVERY member is a high school OR undergrad college student.

Best use of Rebar Shield on Alkanes
$4,250 of Bitcoin
1 winner

$4,250 in bitcoin - For the project that best utilizes Rebar Shield within the Alkanes ecosystem.

Rebar Shield is a specialized RPC service that enables Bitcoin transactions to be submitted directly to mining pools, bypassing the public mempool for faster and more private settlement. This prize will be awarded to the best application of Rebar Shield within the Alkanes ecosystem, a smart contract platform built on Bitcoin. Projects should highlight creative, secure, and effective uses of Rebar Shield technology in the context of Alkanes.

Read the full challenge description & submission requirements here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1L0AEkmfAsw8pRh2uC43QqnAI4kQyzoVDmrvI72WVjgk/edit?usp=sharing

Sponsored by Rebar Labs - https://rebarlabs.io

Best use of Rebar Data
$7,000 of Bitcoin
1 winner

$7,000 in bitcoin - For the project that demonstrates the most impactful, creative, or technically impressive use of Rebar Data in their solution.

Rebar Data is Rebar Labs' enterprise-grade data platform, offering rich, comprehensive information on Bitcoin and its emerging metaprotocols. This challenge invites participants to build innovative applications that leverage the depth and breadth of Rebar Data. This prize will be awarded to the project that demonstrates the most impactful, creative, or technically impressive use of Rebar Data in their solution.

Read the full challenge description & submission requirements here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1L0AEkmfAsw8pRh2uC43QqnAI4kQyzoVDmrvI72WVjgk/edit?usp=sharing

Sponsored by Rebar Labs - https://rebarlabs.io

Best use of BIP300
$11,250 of Bitcoin
1 winner

1st Place - $7250 in bitcoin
2nd Place - $4000 in bitcoin

Background: LayerTwo Labs creates P2P sidechains of Bitcoin — these are the real deal: merged-mined, no custodians, no alt-token, no federation, no multi-sig. We have already created "thunder" (which can scale to 8 billion users), "zSide" (which has zCash-like privacy), and BitNames (which is Namecoin-like). In the past we created "EthSide" a clone of geth.

Challenge: Check out our software at LayerTwoLabs.com/download, and make something new! For example — make a better version of the launcher, or improve the performance of Thunder, or make a multi-chain block explorer, or make SPV / mobile wallets, or a new useful L2 chain — or anything else. Let inspiration strike!

Sponsored by https://LayerTwoLabs.com
judging:
Judging Criteria

  • Routine Difficulty
    Quality of your Project Idea. Potential impact of your idea. Ambition/scope of the project.
  • Routine Execution
    Project achievement. What you actually built. Does it work? Were you able to solve the problem you set out to solve?
  • General Effect
    Swag Factor, Presentation, Applicability to Bitcoin

description:
About the Challenge

Hackonomics 2025 allows individuals passionate about finance, economics, and computer science in our community to fuse the aforementioned principles via projects with the potential to have a positive impact on our community.

NOTE: This hackathon is currently still gathering sponsors and prizes are TBD. You can view our last event, Hackonomics 2024.

Getting Started

Brainstorm project ideas, approaches to outreach, and potential impact. Additionally, join the discord server for more details on the event.
requirements:
Requirements

What to Build

Create an innovative project, product, business, or idea that would help spread awareness about financial literacy and economics in the community.

This Hackathon is open-ended and beginner-friendly hackathon and allows submissions covering the wide range of economic or financial topics. We also allow submissions in all mediums and different stages of development.

What to Submit

A YouTube video or Google Drive video describing your project (1-2 Minutes Recommended, 5 Minutes Maximum) and a document of the source program (any medium). Designs, prototypes, and submissions from Hackonomics 2024 are permitted. See criteria for more information.
prizes:
Prizes

5 non-cash prizes
First Place
1 winner

Most effective in satisfying criteria of all submitted projects.

Second Place
1 winner

Second most effective in satisfying criteria of all submitted projects.

Third Place
1 winner

Third most effective in satisfying criteria of all submitted projects.

Design Award
2 winners

Incorporates a sleek, user-friendly, and polished design, maximizing accessibility of project content. (May be a Figma-based project or prototype.)

Technical Award
2 winners

Projects that demonstrate the best application by using data and integration to create a comprehensive app that covers all aspects of the project's task.
judging:
Judging Criteria

  • Relevancy
    How well does the project address the theme of economics and financial literacy while combining code? Does it also include an element of educating others on the topic?
  • Technical Execution
    How well is the project built? Does it demonstrate a high level of technical proficiency, scalability, and efficiency? Is the implementation technically sound?
  • Presentation
    How visually appealing and user-friendly is the project? Is the design intuitive, with a clear and attractive user interface, thoughtful color schemes, and a seamless user experience?
  • Impact
    What is the potential impact of the project? Could it have meaningful applications or scale beyond Hackonomics? Does it offer long-term value in terms of user benefit, business, or societal impact?
  • Innovation
    How unique or creative is the approach to solving the problem? Does the project push boundaries or introduce novel ideas or technologies?

description:
Welcome to AmpliCode Hackathon 2025!

This hackathon is all about creativity, problem-solving, and real-world impact. Whether you're a beginner or an experienced coder, this is your chance to build something meaningful while pushing your skills to the next level.

Participants will be challenged to create projects based on three key themes, each addressing an important global need:

Hackathon Themes/Tracks

  1. Future of Learning – Design tools that make education more engaging, accessible, and effective through technology.

  2. AI for Good – Develop AI-driven solutions that help communities, improve accessibility, or solve social challenges.

  3. Security & Online Safety – Build projects that protect digital identities, promote cybersecurity awareness, or enhance online privacy.

  4. Open Innovation – Have a groundbreaking idea that doesn’t fit into a category? Build anything you want and bring your vision to life!

 

Why Join?

  • Beginner-friendly – No experience? No problem! Learn as you build.

  • Real-world impact – Solve meaningful challenges through technology.

  • Collaboration & networking – Connect with innovators and potential teammates.

  • Showcase your skills – Create a project that stands out.

 

How to Get Started

  1. Join Our Discord (https://discord.gg/TqDvsvT7Kf) – Meet participants, find teammates, and stay updated.

  2. Explore Our Website (https://www.amplicode.org/) – Find more details about the hackathon, access free coding resources, and take advantage of courses to enhance your skills.

  3. Choose a Theme – Pick one of the three challenge areas and start brainstorming.

  4. Start Planning – Brainstorm ideas for your project.

Let’s code, create, and amplify innovation together!
requirements:
Requirements

  • Demo Video – Submit a 2-minute (or less) video showcasing your project. Your video must begin with:
    • "Hey, I'm [Your Name], and this is my demo for AmpliCode Hackathon 2025."

  • Choose a Theme – During submission, select one of the four hackathon themes (Future of Learning, AI for Good, Security & Online Safety, or Open Innovation). Prizes will be awarded based on these tracks.

  • Public Repository – Your project code must be in a public repository and remain accessible post-event for prize eligibility.

  • Registration Completion – Ensure you’ve completed all Devpost registration steps before submitting.

  • Fresh Submissions Only – All projects must be built during the hackathon. No prior work or cross-submissions to other hackathons are allowed.

  • Team Size – No minimum or maximum limit, but teams of up to 4 tend to perform best.

judging:
Judging Criteria

  • Creativity & Innovation
    How unique and original is the project? Does it introduce a fresh perspective or solve a problem in a novel way?
  • Technical Complexity
    How advanced or well-executed is the technical implementation? Does the project demonstrate strong coding skills, effective problem-solving, or innovative use of technology?
  • User Experience & Design
    Is the project intuitive and user-friendly? Does it provide a seamless and engaging experience with thoughtful design and functionality?
  • Overall Presentation & Impact
    How well is the project communicated in the submission? Does the demo effectively showcase the idea, and does the project have potential for real-world impact?

description:
CodePi Innovation Challenge!

To all who are interested in PARTICIPATING or JUDGING, please join the Discord Server at https://discord.gg/Cc3EAq3wFp for further information and announcements.

Also, feel free to claim your NordVPN participation prize here and your NordPass participation prize here!

Welcome to the CodePi Innovation Challenge, a hackathon organized by students, for students! Here, innovation meets STEM through the art of coding. This challenge is your chance to combine creativity, problem-solving, and technology to craft unique projects that bring STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math) concepts to life. Whether you're an experienced coder or just starting your journey, we’re here to inspire you to build something amazing that makes STEM fun, engaging, and impactful.

This challenge is all about using coding to spark curiosity and make math exciting and engaging. You might create an educational app that helps students master fractions and decimals, a fun game that teaches basic algebra concepts, an interactive website that visualizes geometric shapes, or a prototype that turns math word problems into puzzles. Whatever your idea, we want to see how you can use the power of programming to simplify math, encourage exploration, and make learning enjoyable for middle schoolers.

At the CodePi Innovation Challenge, we celebrate fresh ideas, technical skills, and the drive to innovate. Whether you're crafting low-code prototypes or developing fully functional applications, this is your opportunity to showcase your creativity and passion for STEM. Together, let’s redefine how coding and STEM can come together to make learning more interactive, inspiring, and impactful for the future generation of innovators.

To check out past winners, look at our website here!
requirements:
Requirements

What to Build

Participants can create projects in one of two divisions:

  • Ideathon Division:
    Perfect for beginners or those with minimal coding experience!

    • Build creative, low-code, or no-code projects like mockups, prototypes, or designs.

    • Use tools like Figma, Canva, or Scratch to visually showcase your idea.

    • Focus on crafting innovative ideas that connect coding with STEM concepts.

  • Hackathon Division:
    Designed for experienced coders and developers!

    • Build fully functional apps, games, or websites that explore STEM concepts using coding.

    • Use programming languages or tools like Python, JavaScript, HTML/CSS, or Scratch.

    • Ensure your project demonstrates how coding enhances STEM learning or solves STEM-related problems.

What to Submit

  1. Project Description:

    • A brief write-up explaining what your project does and how it works.

    • Clearly specify whether your project is for the Ideathon or Hackathon division.

  2. Code Repository (Hackathon Division Only):

    • Include a link to your source code (e.g., GitHub repository).

  3. Video Submission:

    • Submit a video no longer than 5 minutes.

    • Your video should explain:

      • What your project is about.

      • How it works.

      • How it connects coding with STEM concepts.

      • Any unique or creative features you’ve added.

  4. Prototype or Design Files (Ideathon Division Only):

    • Share links or attachments for mockups, designs, or prototypes created with tools like Figma or Canva.

judging:
Judging Criteria

  • Creativity and Innovation (25%)
    How unique and original is the idea? Does the project creatively integrate coding with STEM concepts? Is the approach fresh and exciting for middle schoolers?
  • STEM Integration (25%)
    How well does the project align with STEM principles (Science, Technology, Engineering, or Math)? Does the project demonstrate a clear connection between coding and STEM topics? Is it effective in teaching or exploring STEM concepts?
  • Feasibility and Clarity (20%) (Ideathon Division only)
    Is the proposed project realistic and achievable? Are the design, mockups, or prototypes clear and well-thought-out? Does the submission clearly show how the idea can be implemented?
  • Technical Execution (20%) (Hackathon Division only)
    Is the project functional and well-built? Is the code clean, efficient, and well-documented? Does the project use appropriate tools or programming languages effectively?
  • Presentation and Communication (20%)
    How clear and engaging is the video submission? Does it explain the purpose, functionality, and STEM connection of the project well? Is the project visually appealing and easy to understand?
  • Impact and Usability (10%)
    How practical or impactful is the project for its intended audience? Can it be used by middle schoolers to learn STEM concepts easily? Does it have potential for further development or scalability?
